title-group.article-title: Degradation effects in polyester and vinyl ester resins induced by accelerated aging in seawater

article-meta.aff: Industrial Chemistry and Material Engineering Department, Engineering Faculty, University of Messina, Vill. S. Agata, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Annamaria Visco, Facoltà d’Ingegneria, Dipartimento di Chimica Industriale ed Ingegneria dei Materiali, Università di Messina, Contrada Di Dio, Vill. S. Agata, I-98166 Messina, Italy Email: avisco@unime.it

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This research is a study on the degradation effects caused by seawater absorption of isophthalic polyester and vinyl ester resin employed in boat manufacture. Physical and mechanical tests of the resins were performed before and after the degradation. The results highlighted that the polyester resin is more degraded than the vinyl one, due to a different network organization of the two materials. The polyester has a biphasic structure with a low compactness, so water diffusion into the bulk is highly favored. The degradation occurs mainly by the leaching of small molecules extracted from the resin bulk by the water. Damages (cracks, holes, blisters) are evident and the resin loses its mechanical performance. The vinyl network is monophasic and compact, so avoids the entry of water; its degradation occurs differently, by a hydrolytic surface erosion of resin layers. In this way, it retains its bulk better compared to the polyester one.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Organic thermoset resins, such as the polyester and vinyl ester, are commonly used in fiber-reinforced polymer-matrix composite materials, or ‘FRPs.’ These are widely employed in boat manufacture.

Polyester resins, as well as the vinyl ester ones, are widely used in coating technology. The polyester is inexpensive and it can easily accommodate defined specifications by changing its chemical formulation (such as the nature of unsaturated polyester chain and/or the styrene/polyester ratio amount). For vinyl ester resin, there is a considerable commercial interest: the higher cost compared to the polyester one is due to the higher resistance to degradation by corrosive and hostile environments.1

The application of FRPs on boats or other vessels has been accompanied by the study of durability in water contact or humid atmosphere in order to optimize their design.2 Considerable attention was already given to the effects of adsorbed water on the mechanical behavior of FRPs.3 The absorption mechanisms can be thermally improved since the amount of water absorbed as well as the degree of damage produced increase greatly as the immersion temperature increases.4
The adsorbed water generally leads to a reduction in mechanical properties by weakening the interfacial fiber/matrix bond or by plasticizing the matrix where a great degradation effect occurs.5

Despite the experimental evidence on the effects of a humid environment upon the fibers (the glass one, in particular),6 the matrix degradation is the main parameter governing the laminate durability. The water uptake commonly induces loss of adhesive strength, swelling, hydrolysis, leaching of small molecules, and osmotic cracking.

For example, in the unsaturated polyester resins (UPS), these damages ensue from the diffusion of water molecules throughout the polymeric chains. This causes plasticization, local strain, rupture of the chains, and chemical reactions.7

Gautier at al.8 have already studied the osmotic cracking in the UPS. They concluded that it is promoted by the glycols accumulated in the polymeric network after the hydrolytic chain scission reactions.

Fraga et al.9 highlighted that the water gain of UPS could be due to voids produced during the cure reaction for the styrene volatilization. They did not observe a chemical degradation of the polyester (or vinyl ester) resin and concluded that the plasticization of the macromolecular network is due to the extraction of small soluble chain from the matrix. The vinyl ester resin, as well as the polyester one, contains styrene as the cross-linking agent. Experimental results highlighted that the vinyl ester resin avoids the seawater uptake better compared to the polyester one.

The importance of the voids in a material have been highlighted also by Thomason et al., who found a linear proportionality between the void level and the rate of water uptake in glassy/epoxy composite laminates. In this case, the void content was more significant than the interface fiber/matrix adhesion in enhancing absorption.10 Mouritz et al.6 evidenced a chemical modification of the undercured and the full-cured polyester and vinyl ester-based composites aged at 30°C in seawater. This last result was in discordance with the Fraga’s one above discussed.

In order to better understand all the factors that regulate the degradation mechanisms of the resins (besides their chemical hydrolytic reactions),11,12 in this work, we have investigated the degradation behavior of two matrices (a vinyl ester and a polyester isophthalic) immersed in seawater at 60°C for a long time. During this accelerated aging, we tested both the hardness and resilience changes of the resins.

In a previous study, we related the diffusion and permeation of water into the matrix to the polymeric structure.13 In particular, the lower free volume of the vinyl ester resin network (compared to the polyester one) avoided the water gain, so the resin showed a better durability in seawater presence.14 So, the aim of this article was the correlation between the kinds of the damage of the materials and the structural features of the two resins.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Isophthalic polyester resin (Synolite 0288 PA) with a viscosity at 20 s−1 of 390–470 (mPaxs), gel time from 25 to 35°C of 17–19 min, styrene content of 45% by weight and vinyl ester resin (DISTITRON®, VE100 ST) with a viscosity at 20 s−1 of 600–850 (mPaxs), gel time from 25 to 35°C of 34–41 min, and styrene content of 44–49% by weight were supplied by Royal DSM N.V. Company (DSM) and by Polynt, respectively, and catalyzed with 2% of Butanox 50 M. The chemical formulation of the repeating units of isophtalic polyester resin (1) and that of the vinyl ester resin (2) are reported in the following: (1) (2)

Resin samples were prepared in the laboratory of the Engineering Faculty of Messina, by a curing process of 14 days at room temperature in polymeric moulds, as commonly used in the most composites manufacturing.15 They were codified as ‘ISO’ and ‘VINYL.’

sec.title: Accelerated aging tests
sec.p: Accelerated aging test of resins was carried out at a temperature of 60°C in a thermostatic bath (Nube NB20) containing seawater, according to ASTM D570 standard. Sample dimensions were 12 mm × 70 mm × 5 mm (width × length × thickness).

Before each test, samples were dried in an oven (Lloyd TC 540) for 24 h at 50°C and then they were placed in a desiccator, until they were cooled. Afterwards, the samples were weighed by a OHAUS Explorer Pro balance with sensibility of 0.1 mg. A constant water level was always maintained by adding distilled water. The samples were removed from the bath periodically within the range of 1–1440 h, dried with a lint-free cloth, and weighed.

Water absorption percentage was expressed as: (3)Water absorption=(Pw-PDPD)×100, where Pw is the wet weight and PD is the dry weight of the sample. Water diffusion coefficient or diffusivity (D) was calculated by the Equation15: (4)D=π(h4M∞)2(M∞-M1t∞-t1)2(1+hL+hw)-2, where h, L, and w are thickness, length, and width of the resin sample, M1 and M∞ are moisture contests at time t1 and t∞, respectively. t1 is the initial time (0 h) and t∞ is the time at which the moisture content became constant or maximum (M∞).

sec.title: Calorimetric analysis
sec.p: Calorimetric analysis was performed by a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC), TA Instruments Q100, equipped with a Universal Analysis 2000 TA Instruments software. The calorimeter was previously calibrated with indium standard.
Samples of liquid resins were mixed with catalyst and cured isothermally (at room temperature) for different times over 3 months.

Each sample weight was about 10 mg. After curing, the resin samples were introduced in the DSC module and tested. The result of DSC analysis was the average of three samples for each curing time. The DSC test was performed by heating from room temperature up to 180°C, with a rate of 10°C min−1, under nitrogen flow (50 mL min−1).

The DSC analysis gave the residual enthalpy of curing (ΔH), allowing to determine the apparent degree of conversion, α, and the glass transition temperature, Tg.16 The conversion degree, α, was calculated by the following equation: (5)α=1-ΔHiΔHtot, where ΔHi is the heat of reaction measured at the i-esimum cure reaction time at room temperature and ΔHtot is the heat of reaction measured at the cure time t = 0 min.

sec.title: Density measurements
sec.p: Density values of the resins were calculated by measuring the sample weight by an electronic balance, mod. Adventurer Ohaus, with sensibility of ±0.01 g. Density values (ρ) were calculated by the equation: (6)ρ=ρ0(AA-B), where ρ0 is the fluid density (water), A is the sample weight in air, and B is the sample weight in liquid.

sec.title: Contact angle measurements
sec.p: Contact angle measurements were carried out according to the sessile drop technique and performed by the contact angle micrometer.17 In order to measure the wetting angles, pure distilled water, at 20°C temperature, was employed to deposit 1 µL drop on the polymer surface.

The water drop was deposited accurately with a microsyringe on the sample surfaces. The contact angle θ was measured by a Charge Coupled Device (CCD) camera through the optical image (×10 magnification) captured by a suitable personal computer (PC) images software.

The contact angle was measured through the following equation: (7)θ=2arctan(Hr). where H is the height of a droplet and r is the radius of the droplet base. For each sample, the average value was calculated for 10 drops measurements.
As known, the contact angle θ relative to the wetting case is <90° and to the non-wetting case is >90°.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with a JEOL JSM 5600 LU microscope. The investigations concern the external surface of the resins before and after the aging in seawater. For the SEM investigations, the resin samples were coated in vacuum with a very thin gold film to make them electrically conductive. The electron acceleration voltage was of 10 kV and the photo magnification was of ×70, ×1500 and ×3000.

sec.title: Infrared spectroscopy
sec.p: The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was performed on resin powder by using a spectrometer (Thermo Nicolet ‘Evolution 500’ instrument). In particular, we investigated the following signals: the C–O stretching vibration of ester group (with two signals at wavelength of ∼1230 and ∼1280 cm−1), the C = O stretching vibration of ester group (at wavelength of ∼1725 cm−1), and the C–O stretching vibration of alcohol group (with a signal at wavelength of ∼1040 for VINYL and at wavelength of ∼1070 and for ISO). The shifted value of the ISO compared to the VINYL is related to the chemical interactions of their different structures.18

It is possible to quantify the hydrolytic changes originating from the aging treatments through the determination of hydrolysis indices (HIC − O ester, HIC = 0 ester, and HIC − O alcohol) calculated by the following formulas: (8)HIC-Oester=AC-OesterAref, (9)HIC=Oester=AC=OesterAref, (10)HIC-Oalcohol=AC-OalcoholAref, where Aref is the peak area −CH3, −CH2, and −CH stretching, within the 2750–3130 cm−1 range, chosen as a reference area since its amplitude does not appreciably change after the aging in both resin samples; AC − Oester is the C–O stretching signal of ester group peak area, within the 1190–1340 cm−1 range; AC = 0ester is the C = O stretching signal of ester peak area, within the 1650–1790 cm−1 range; AC − O alcohol is the C–O stretching signal of alcohol group peak area, at 1070 cm−1 for ISO and at 1040 cm−1 for VINYL. The assignation of the peaks was made taking into account previously published literature results.6,9

sec.title: Mechanical tests
sec.p: Hardness measurements, in Vickers units (VH), were performed with a Shimatzu DUH-200 instrument, equipped with a pyramidal-shape diamond tip. The average VH values have been reported on 10 measurements, as results of the following relationship: (11)VH=0.7564F(d1+d2)2, where F represents the applied load (of 3 N) and d1 and d2 the two diagonal lengths (mm) of the pyramidal print produced by the diamond tip on the polymer surface.

Izod resilience test was carried out by a CEAST RESIL IMPACTOR equipped with a 25 J slug (ASTM D256 – 10 international protocols). Samples geometry was 12.7 mm × 64 mm, 4.2 mm thickness. The notch, 2.5 mm deepness, was performed by a CEAST NOTCHVIS with an angle of cut of 45°.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In this first part of the experimentation, we studied the spontaneous (natural) cross-linking reactions of the two resins at room temperature, by means of a calorimetric investigation.

The DSC heat-flux curves of both pristine ISO and the VINYL resin are shown in Figures 1(a) and 2(a), respectively. This analysis was performed during a period of 3 months (equal to 129600 min). In particular, the calorimetric analysis measured the exothermic reaction, heat developed by resin samples cured at room temperature (25°C) for 0, 50, 180, 1440, 10,800, 43200, and 129600 min. In Table 1, the enthalpy (ΔH) and conversion degree (α) values measured for each cure reaction time are detailed. By observing the values and comparing the DSC curves of the two resins at the same reaction time, it is evident that the reaction rate of ISO resin is faster than VINYL one. For example, the VINYL resin reaches a conversion degree value of 89% after 10080 min, while the ISO one reaches a similar conversion degree (of 85%) after only 180 min. Furthermore, the cure reaction of the ISO resin is quite complete after 3 months (α = 0.98), while the VINYL network is still reacting at that time, since its conversion value is lower (α = 0.93). Figure 1.
Heat flux of ISO resin samples cured for different times vs. the temperature (a) and an expansion of some curves (b). Figure 2.
Heat flux of VINYL resin samples cured for different times vs. the temperature (a) and an expansion of some curves (b). Table 1.
Differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) parameters of the VINYL and ISO resins with increasing cure time at T = 25°C
Resin Code Cure time at 25°C (min) ΔH (J/g) Conversion degree α
0 250.2 0.00
50 108.4 0.57
90 69.9 0.72
VINYL 180 60.6 0.80
1440 56.7 0.84
10080 37.78 0.89
43200 34.21 0.92
129600 35.34 0.93
1 286.4 0.00
50 106.4 0.64
90 54.18 0.82
ISO 180 47.98 0.85
1440 31.44 0.92
10800 21.26 0.93
43200 14.47 0.95
129600 5.78 0.98

The same DSC curves show that the exothermic peaks of ISO resin appears larger than the VINYL one. The DSC curves recorded after 50 min (Figure 1(a)) and those recorded after 1440, 10800, and 43200 min resolves into two subpeaks (Figure 1(b)). The presence of two subpeaks at about 76°C and at 90°C (see the arrows in the pictures) suggest a bi-phase network organization of the ISO resin network.

While, the VINYL network organizes itself in one structure, in fact the DSC analysis revealed by a unique peak during its formation. The expansion of the exothermic peaks in Figure 2(b) always shows one peak for each reaction time. The two peaks of ISO resin can be due to the main cross-linked polyester network and to the several styrene units or polystyrene homopolymer.14 Instead, the VINYL monomers directly convert to a high molecular weight polymeric network, without the generation of polystyrene chains. This highlights that the two materials cross-link in a different way forming different macromolecular structures.

The presence of the polystyrene chains play an important role, since they are between the polyester isophthalic chains and improve the free volume into the ISO network. Instead, little styrene monomer units bond the vinyl ester chains, so the VINYL bulk has a higher compactness.

So, if on the one hand, the cross-linking reaction of VINYL resin is slower compared to the ISO one, on the other hand, its network was higher densely packed. In fact, the structural organization of the VINYL resin shows a lower free volume that avoids better the entry of water into the network compared to the ISO one. The different resin structure also depends on the chemical organization of the repetition unit that is more linear in the vinyl ester compared to the polyester isophthalic chains. This aspect was studied and already evidenced in our previous article.14 So, these DSC results are in agreement with the results previously published and confirms the evidence of the polystyrene homopolymer formation in the ISO resin.

Finally, a careful observation of the DSC curves of both resins highlights the presence of small peaks at ∼115–120°C (in the ISO) and ∼ 125°C (in the VINYL). These peaks can be due to oligomers species, which moves with difficulty into the thermoset network. Higher temperatures are necessary for these species in order to diffuse into the network, especially at higher conversions.

In the second part of the study, we observed the network degradation of the resins by the accelerated aging test in seawater correlated with mechanical measurements. Several ISO and VINYL samples were prepared to know their durability behavior in a water environment.

In order to develop the resin network in a natural way and to obtain a high cure degree, all the samples were cured for 14 days at room temperature and then heated (or postcured) at 50°C for 1 day before their immersion (see Section Accelerated aging tests). Besides, mechanical hardness and impact tests were performed on the same resin samples before and during the accelerated aging test.

Table 2 lists the enthalpy (ΔH), the conversion degree (α), and the glass transition temperature (Tg) values of the samples used for the accelerated aging test. Table 2.
Differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) parameters of the VINYL and ISO resins differently postcured
Resin Code Cure time at T = 25°C [days] Post –Cure time [days] Post –Cure temperature [°C] ΔH (J/g) Conversion degree α Tg (°C)
VINYL 14 – – 48.3 0.90 45.7
14 1 50 14.9 0.94 72.6
ISO 14 – – 37.9 0.93 43.5
14 1 50 11.6 0.97 66.7

All DSC parameters depend on the postcure treatment. As expected, the conversion degree and the Tg values improve after the postcure treatment. The cure degree of the VINYL and ISO resins at the moment of immersion into the seawater was of 0.94 and 0.97, respectively.

The Tg values of VINYL were always higher than ISO at equal cure or postcure treatment. This confirmed the higher structural compactness of VINYL network compared to the ISO one, according to the DSC results, previously discussed.

The results of water uptake measurements on the two thermoset resins are shown in Figure 3. Water absorption in polymers is often analyzed in terms of Fickian diffusion, which requires that the results are plotted as mass change percentage vs. square root of time.19 The ISO and VINYL resins have produced a classical water absorption curve, with an initial linear increase in weight leveling off to a plateau equilibrium value. The VINYL resin showed a much higher water absorption resistance compared to the ISO one. In particular, the maximum water gain of VINYL was of ∼0.6% (after 11 days), while for ISO it was double, ∼1.2% after 33 days of immersion. Figure 3.
Water absorption of ISO and VINYL resins immersed in seawater at 60°C for 5 months and relative photos of the samples after the immersion time of 0, 45 , and 156 days.

In Table 3 the D and M∞ values of the two resins are detailed. The diffusivity of ISO resin (1.22 × 10−6 mm2 s−1) resulted higher than the VINYL one (0.97 × 10−6 mm2 s−1). The higher VINYL resin water absorption resistance than the ISO one was already evidenced by literature data20 and it is in agreement with the different network organization already discussed. Table 3.
Density, wet ability, and diffusivity parameters of ISO and VINYL resins
Code ρ [g/cm3] wet ability θ [°] D [x 10−6 mm2/s] M∞ [%]
ISO 1.18 95.5 ± 3.1 1.22 ± 0.23 1.209
VINYL 1.15 95.1 ± 2.4 0.97 ± 0.07 0.611

The density values of ISO resulted 1.18 g cm−3 and that of VINYL is of 1.15 g cm−3. These values are the starting density, before the immersion of the resin. Considering that the starting conversion degree of the two resin is α = 0.97 for ISO and α = 0.94 for VINYL (see Table 2), the lower density of the VINYL compared to that of ISO is due to the not complete cross-link reactions. These latter will be completed during the immersion in seawater, as demonstrated in our already published article,14 and consequently, the density will change. Besides, the resins have a comparable starting wet ability (around 95°).

The color of the material and its consistency change during the immersion period. In particular, in the inset of Figure 3, three photographs of both resin samples taken after 0, 45, and 156 days of immersion in seawater at 60°C are shown. The yellow starting color of ISO (t = 0 days) transforms into a progressive darkened orange (t = 45 days). The yellow transparent starting color of the VINYL (t = 0 days) transforms into a progressive darkened yellow-brown one (after 45 days). Both materials lost their starting transparency becoming opaque and whitened, especially after a high-aged time (156 days).

The optical color variations showed during the accelerated aging of the resins suggested that physical and chemical changes occur in the thermoset resins. The materials modify their structure during water immersion because the seawater, present in the polymeric network, reacts with the material degrading it by means of hydrolytic reactions and/or by the leaching of small molecules (monomers or oligomers).

It is well known that ester groups present in both resins easily react with water. The vinyl ester resin exhibits a higher chemical stability compared to the polyester isophthalic one.6 This is due to the nature of ester groups: isophatalates and fumarates in ISO resin, methacrylates in VINYL one. It is known that the isophatalates and fumarates groups are less resistant to the hydrolysis than the methacrylates.12 The higher chemical stability of the VINYL can be explained by considering also another aspect: its more compact polymeric network permit a lower water gains, so that it is less subjected to the degradation reactions (such as hydrolysis and/or small molecules leaching).

The higher stability of the VINYL resin is also confirmed by the hardness measurements performed in the internal cross section of each sample. In particular, in Figure 4, the Di/D0 ratio values of the two resins vs. the immersion time are plotted. The general trend is a hardness decrease of both resins up to a constant value. A careful observation of the hardness data (Table 4) suggests that the decrease of both resins occurs in two steps. In the first step, the Di/D0 ratio decreases slightly (from 1.0 to 0.96 after 15 days of ISO immersion and from 1.0 to 0.94 after 30 days of VINYL immersion). During this initial period, in fact, both resins are completing their cross-linking reaction, especially the less-cured VINYL resin compared to the ISO one. Here, the water plasticization action is contrasted by the formation of new cross-links. Then, the Di/D0 ratio decreases again (second step) and stabilizes around an average value of 0.86 and 0.92 for ISO and VINYL, respectively. These results highlighted that when the cure reaction is complete, the water plasticization/degradation reaction starts and becomes prevailing. Figure 4.
Normalized Vickers hardness of ISO and VINYL resin immersed in seawater at 60°C for 5 months. Table 4.
Relative Vickers hardness and Izod impact strength of ISO and VINYL resins immersed in seawater at 60°C for 5 months
Relative Vickers hardness Di/D0 Izod Impact Strength [J/m2]
Immersion time [days] ISO VINYL ISO VINYL
0 1.00 ± 0.01 1.00 ± 0.03 1000.6 ± 10.5 1054,5 ± 54.5
15 0.96 ± 0.01 0.95 ± 0.01 1249.0 ± 14.3 1318.1 ± 58.1
30 0.86 ± 0.00 0.94 ± 0.01 1324.9 ± 38.0 1195.8 ± 35.6
45 0.86 ± 0.01 0.89 ± 0.01 1185.3 ± 12.4 1040.4 ± 73.8
60 0.85 ± 0.01 0.90 ± 0.05 1105.7 ± 2.5 1043.7 ± 31.8
85 0.87 ± 0.01 0.90 ± 0.01 1057.4 ± 8.7 1086.7 ± 30.0
126 0.86 ± 0.01 0.92 ± 0.00 1061.9 ± 3.0 1094.3 ± 2.3
141 0.88 ± 0.02 0.92 ± 0.00 1082.2 ± 12.2 1120.6 ± 74.2
156 0.87 ± 0.00 0.91 ± 0.00 1106.1 ± 45.9 1130.1 ± 76.4

Furthermore, the decrease of the ISO resin hardness is always higher than the VINYL one. This suggests that the VINYL resin retains better its polymeric structure in seawater compared to the ISO one for all investigated immersion time. The higher chemical stability, together with the macromolecular structure compactness, avoids the water degradation reaction in the polymeric bulk.

Also, the resilience of the two resins changes during the immersion time, as suggested by the plot of Figure 5 and the values listed in Table 4. The two resin curves have a similar behavior that can be divided in three parts (I, II, and III), described in the following. Figure 5.
Impact strength of ISO and VINYL resin immersed in seawater at 60°C for 5 months.

In the first part of the graph (part I), the resilience of both materials increases due to the water absorption and its plasticization action. The starting resilience value of the ISO resin is of 1054 J m−2, while the VINYL one is lower (1000 J m−2). The ISO resilience is higher than VINYL, due to its higher starting conversion degree value (αISO = 97% and αVINYL = 94%). During the first period of immersion, the resilience improves in a wider time in the ISO resin (30 days) compared to the VINYL (15 days). This is due to the high hydrophilic character of the isophthalic polyester resin, according to the water absorption measurements presented in Figure 2.

In the second part of the graph (part II), the resilience decreases because of the cross-link reactions occurring in the resins. They complete their cure helped by the bath temperature of 60°C. The VINYL resin starts its cross-linking reaction earlier than the ISO one, in agreement with its high tendency to complete its cure reaction.14 The VINYL resin is less resilient than the ISO one, since it completes its cure reaction and it absorbs few water molecules into its network.

After about 85 days of immersions (part III), the resilience of the two resins became very close to each other, suggesting a change of mechanical behavior of the materials compared to the previous phase II. This is due to the degradation reactions that occur after a very long contact with the seawater. Besides, in the phase III, the ISO resin resilience values became lower than the VINYL one. This inversion of mechanical behavior can be due to the different degradation mode of the two materials. The lower resilience of ISO samples is in agreement with higher water absorption and the consequent higher damages induced in their polymeric network compared to the VINYL ones.
The resilience behavior described above is also in agreement with what has already been shown in literature by Apicella et al. for the polyester resins.11

The Figure 6(a)–(d) shows the SEM micrographs of the two resins surface before ((a) and (c)) and after 156 days of immersion in seawater ((b) and (d)). The images highlight clearly a change in the surface morphologies. The whitened areas are due to the seawater salts stored on the polymer surface, they appear more uniformly distributed upon the VINYL surface compared to the ISO one. Figure 6.
Scanning electron micrographs of VINYL and ISO resin before ((a) and (c)) and after ((b) and (d)) the seawater immersion for 5 months at 60°C.

Some magnifications of the degraded surfaces are depicted in Figures 7 and 8. Figure 7(a) and (b) show a particular of the ISO surface (at ×1500 and ×3000 magnification, respectively): some cavities appear, about 5–10 µm wide, interconnected by microcracks (Figure 7(a)). On the same surface, other small cavities are also visible (of the order of few microns). They are surrounded by an irregular deposition of marine salts. Other small cavities of the nanometer order are visible in the inner part of these cavities (Figure 7(b)). Figure 7.
Scanning electron micrographs of ISO resin immersed in seawater at 60°C for 5 months at magnitude ×1500 (a) and ×3000 (b). Figure 8.
Scanning electron micrographs of VINYL resin immersed in seawater at 60°C for 5 months at magnitude ×1500 (a) and ×3000 (b).

The VINYL resin shows a more regular surface. This surface appears excavated by the seawater erosion but no cavities or breaks appear on the surface (Figure 8(a), magnification of ×1500). A wider magnification at ×3000 confirms the absence of holes and highlights the uniform marine salt deposition on the surface.

The SEM micrographs highlighted that the ISO resin network is degraded in a different way compared to the VINYL one. The lower compactness of the ISO network aids a high water gain in its bulk. Water molecules can come in the polymeric network forming little blisters; according to the osmotic process, the microblister sizes increase. This process was described by Gautier et al.21 as: initialization (defect nucleation), propagation (crack formation), and arrest (blister cavity formation).

Then, the pressure of the entrapped water opens the blisters generating the cavities with micropores and the cracks visible on the SEM images. The water diffuses into these voids and reacts, degrading the material. The color change and transparency loss confirm the degradation reactions (hydrolysis of ester groups and/or small molecules leaching) in the plasticized materials.
The presence of cavities and cracks into the ISO resin could explain the lower hardness and resilience values compared to the VINYL one.

In the VINYL resin, instead, the absence of cavities, holes or breaks, suggests that the seawater degradation takes away irregular thin surface layers of resin. In fact, the picture of Figure 8(a) shows irregular islands of resin surrounded by a large seawater salt deposition. The salts are below the resin isles. This subtraction of the resin layers aids a better retention of bulk properties (hardness and the resilience) of the VINYL resin compared to the ISO one.

Finally in Figures 9 and 10, the FTIR determination of the ISO and VINYL resin samples before (pristine sample) and after 156 days immersion in seawater (aged sample) is presented. In particular, we investigated the external layer of the resins with the aim to support the SEM results. This analysis was performed in order to understand better if a chemical change occurs in the resins surface during their aging in seawater. Figures 9(a) and 10(a) show the wide FTIR spectrum (within the 500–4000 cm−1 range), while the Figures 9(b) (for ISO) and 10(b) (for VINYL) evidence a magnification of part of each FTIR spectrum (within the 500–2000 cm−1 range). Figure 9.
FTIR spectra (a) and its magnification (b) of the ISO resin pristine and aged for 156 days. Figure 10.
FTIR spectra (a) and its magnification (b) of the VINYL resin pristine and aged for 156 days.

The spectra of both resins are qualitatively the same at the initial and final time. Instead, they change quantitatively after the aging in seawater. In Table 5, the HIC − O ester, HIC = O ester, and HIC − O alcohol of all studied samples are listed. The HIC − O ester and HIC = O ester signals of the pristine ISO resin are 0.803 and 0.874, respectively. These values are higher compared to the pristine VINYL one (0.452 and 0.436, respectively). In particular, both signals investigated (C–O ester stretching vibration at 1230 and ∼1280 cm−1 and ester carbonyl, C = O, at wavelength of ∼1725 cm−1) decreased after the accelerated aging. This result suggests that the ester bond rupture due to the hydrolytic degradation results in the decrease of the ester bond signals concentration. Table 5.
FTIR quantitative analysis performed on ISO and VINYL resins, pristine and aged for 156 days
Sample code treatment HICOester HIC = Oester HICOalcohol
ISO pristine 0.803 0.874 0.110
ISO aged 0.727 0.851 0.125
VINYL pristine 0.452 0.436 0.062
VINYL aged 0.337 0.269 0.086

In particular, the decrease is very low in the ISO resin (the HIC − O ester decrease is 9% and the HIC = O ester decrease is 2.6%, after the aging), while it is more consistent in the VINYL resin (the HIC − O ester decrease is 25% and the HIC = O ester decrease is 38%, after the aging).

The resins show instead an improvement of the C–O peak after the aging in seawater, due to the secondary alcohol bond stretching. This variation in VINYL resin is higher compared to that of the ISO one. In fact, the HIC − O alcohol value, listed in Table 5, of ISO resin (0.110) grows to 0.125 after the aging (with an increase of +13%), while that of VINYL (0.062) improves to 0.086 (with an increase of +38%).

The spectral changes observed in the resins surface are consistent with ester hydrolysis in which ester carbonyl functionality is converted to carboxylic acid and hydroxyl functional groups. This would account for the decrease in carbonyl peak and subsequent increase in the C–O stretching peaks, according to Ghorbel and Valentin.22 In particular, we observed a variation in the C–O stretching, (generally within the range of 1000–1200 cm−1) due to the hydroxyl stretching of alcohol groups.18

These results suggested that the degrading action occurs in both the resins surface, but it is higher in the vinyl ester resin surface compared to the polyester one. As a consequence, a higher amount of hydrolytic reactions occurs in the vinyl resin surface compared to the ISO one. The surface degradation of VINYL resin consists in thin layers detachment, according to the morphology presented by SEM images.

The higher water uptake and diffusivity level of ISO resin (before discussed) can be explained considering that ISO resin degradation occurs mainly in the bulk rather than on its surface. This result is in accordance with the previous morphological SEM and structural DSC results that suggested how the water molecules can easily come in the bulk of the less compact ISO resin, where they can hydrolyze the chemical reactive bonds and/or extract the low molecular weight species. The blisters formation is due to the water entry into the material bulk that starts the osmotic process. Besides, the bulk degradation of ISO resin is in accordance with its higher mechanical performance decrease compared to VINYL one.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, we studied and compared the degradation of two resins, polyester isophthalic and vinyl ester, commonly used in marine field for pleasure boat manufacture.

Several physical and mechanical tests were performed before and after the immersion in seawater at 60°C (accelerated aging test). Both resins were not fully cured at the moment of their immersion in the seawater, so they completed their cure reaction during the immersion.
The values of resilience and hardness of the materials changed due to both cure reaction completion and the plasticization/degradation because of the adsorbed water.

Vinyl ester resin showed to be highly resistant to the water degradation compared to the polyester isophthalic one. The latter resin absorbed a higher water amount due to low compactness of the polymeric network and a higher hydrophilic character.

The low densely packed polyester isophthalic network is due to the presence of long polystyrene chains rather than styrene monomer units. The polystyrene chains during the cross-linking reaction with the polyester chains leave a high amount of free volume between them. This aspect, together with the nonlinearity of the ISO repeating unit, reduces the bulk compactness. The higher hydrophilic character can be explained by considering that the seawater can enter its polymeric network, so the degradation reactions easily occur. In particular, the water molecules can solvate easily the low monomers and/or oligomers which are present in the network (leaching of small molecules). Besides, the chemical reactivity of the ester groups present in the ISO resin allows its degradation. Great defects appear on its surface confirming that water has the possibility to enter the material bulk and decrease the mechanical and chemical features of the material.

A different degradation mechanism occurs in the vinyl ester resin, where the water detaches surface layers of material rather than entering the network. The degradation of vinyl ester resin mainly occurs by surface hydrolytic reactions. So the vinyl ester resin retains better the bulk mechanical and physical behavior compared to the ISO one.

These results highlighted that the structural features of the polymeric matrix has a significant influence on the stability of polyester or vinyl ester-based laminates in seawater. This aspect should be considered together with the well know different chemical reactivity of the ester groups of the two resins.

It is known that the weight gain is different for the undercured and fully cured matrixes. For this reason, further studies are in progress in order to relate the water gain to the resin cure degree. The aim will be to understand the reasons of this behavior and to have more information about the absorption properties of these materials, widely employed in composite laminates.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
